title: Homemade Ketchup Recipe
description: Chef John's homemade ketchup is easy to make in a slow cooker with crushed tomatoes and spices. It's tasty and thick and practically cooks itself.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Side Dish Sauces and Condiments Sauces Homemade Ketchup 4.7 (188) 164 Reviews 14 Photos This homemade ketchup is so easy to make from scratch in a slow cooker. It does come close to those name brands in terms of taste, texture, and color. I've never had a tomato paste-based ketchup that I liked so I decided to cook down crushed tomatoes instead. By John Mitzewich John Mitzewich John Mitzewich — aka Chef John — has produced more than 1,500 cooking videos for Allrecipes. He's the actor, director, and screenwriter whose hands and voice confidently walk you through techniques. Allrecipes' editorial guidelines Updated on January 4, 2024 Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen The Allrecipes Test Kitchen staff are a team of culinary pros who make and vet recipes using only equipment you'd find in a home kitchen. Staff credentials vary but include training at the Culinary Institute of America; kitchen stints in fine dining restaurants; and countless hours in the test kitchen itself. Meet the Allrecipes Test Kitchen Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 14 14 14 14 Prep Time: 10 mins Cook Time: 12 hrs Total Time: 12 hrs 10 mins Servings: 48 Yield: 3 cups Jump to Nutrition Facts Jump to recipe Skip the bottled stuff and learn how to make ketchup at home. This top-rated recipe is beloved by the Allrecipes community for a number of reasons: It's incredibly easy (thanks to your trusty slow cooker), it's made with kitchen staples you likely already have on hand, and it's absolutely delicious. Chef John What Is Ketchup? Ketchup is a tomato-based condiment that's primarily used for dipping or spreading, though it's also commonly featured as an ingredient in other sauces and dressings. It's usually made with tomatoes, vinegar, sugar, and spices and seasonings. Who Invented Ketchup? Early versions of ketchup weren't made with tomatoes. The original ketchups were fish-, mushroom-, nut-, or fruit-based. Before the 19th-century, "ketchup" could refer to any number of sauces with a thick consistency. An American scientist named James Mease is credited with inventing tomato-based ketchup in 1812. His formula was tweaked over the years and in 1876 the famous company, Heinz, debuted its beloved bottled ketchup. Heinz still leads ketchup production today, selling more than 650 million bottles per year. Homemade Ketchup Ingredients Perfect homemade ketchup is easy to make with kitchen staples. Here's what you'll need: TomatoesThis ketchup recipe starts with crushed tomatoes, unlike many other recipes that start with tomato paste. This ingredient swap will get you closer to the flavor and texture of bottled ketchup. VinegarDistilled white vinegar is essential for ketchup's signature tanginess. Plus, it elongates the shelf life. SugarWhite sugar cuts the acidity of the tomatoes and vinegar while offering a hint of sweetness. Spices and SeasoningsThis flavorful ketchup recipe is seasoned with onion powder, garlic powder, salt, celery salt, ground black pepper, mustard powder, and one whole clove. How to Make Ketchup In this recipe, we opt to cook the ketchup in a slow cooker instead of on the stove. Not only does the Crock-Pot take out a lot of the legwork, it also ensures the perfect thick consistency every time. You'll find the full, step-by-step recipe below — but here's a brief overview of what you can expect when you make this ketchup recipe: Pour the tomatoes into the slow cooker, mixing ¼ cup of water with each can. Add the spices and seasonings, then stir to combine. Cook uncovered on high until the mixture is reduced and thick (10 to 12 hours), stirring frequently. Smooth the finished ketchup with an immersion blender and strain. Does Ketchup Need to Be Refrigerated? Yes, homemade ketchup should be refrigerated. Store your ketchup in an airtight container in the fridge for up to three weeks. Can You Freeze Ketchup? Homemade ketchup will freeze well for up to six months. You can freeze it in zip-top freezer bags. Allrecipes Community Tips and Praise "Wow," raves angie. "This recipe came out great. I have two little kids and wanted to make a ketchup without high fructose corn syrup, and to use in our homemade BBQ and sloppy Joe sauces. It tastes just like the bottled stuff." "Great tasting ketchup," according to Sandra Hagan. "Didn't turn out as thick as I liked so I put some of the ketchup in a sauce pot and thickened it with cornstarch. I stirred it into the rest of the ketchup and it was perfect!" "Great recipe," says Melissa Buckler. "I had to change a couple of things based on what I had in my pantry and I cut the sugar in half. Love it though! So happy to have found an easy AND tasty recipe for ketchup." Editorial contributions by Corey Williams Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 48 servings 2 (28 ounce) cans crushed tomatoes ½ cup water, divided ⅔ cup white sugar ¾ cup distilled white vinegar 1 teaspoon onion powder ½ teaspoon garlic powder 1 ¾ teaspoons salt ⅛ teaspoon celery salt ⅛ teaspoon mustard powder ¼ teaspoon finely ground black pepper ¼ teaspoon cayenne pepper, or to taste 1 whole clove Directions Pour tomatoes into slow cooker. Swirl 1/4 cup water in each emptied can and pour into the slow cooker. Add sugar, vinegar, onion powder, garlic powder, salt, celery salt, mustard powder, black pepper, cayenne pepper, and whole clove; whisk to combine. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Cook on High, uncovered, until mixture is reduced by half and very thick, 10 to 12 hours. Stir every hour or so. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Use an immersion blender for about 20 seconds to smooth the texture of the ketchup. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Ladle ketchup into a fine strainer and press mixture with the back of a ladle to strain out any skins and seeds. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Transfer strained ketchup to a bowl. Cool completely. Taste and adjust salt, black pepper, and cayenne pepper as desired. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios I Made It Print 341 home cooks made it! Add Your Photo Photos of Homemade Ketchup 01 of 14 Photo by  Dotdash Meredith Food Studios 02 of 14 Photo by  CyanGrill4978 08/16/2023 Very good taste, too much sugar. I usedmy homegrown tomatoes and had about a quart of it, so more than in the recipe. I put half a cup of sugar plus half a cup of vinegar, so less than what is recommended in the recipe on more tomatoes. The rest of the ingredients were as in the recipe. I cooked it on the stove. It yield less than 3 cups of ketchup. Even with less sugar then recommended it is still super sweet. My kids love it, off course. There is a chance my tomatoes were very sweet to begin with, so next time I will add sugar to taste near the end of cooking. Besides this the taste is excellent and I am making it again. 03 of 14 Photo by  CtUsaMom 05/05/2020 We loved the flavor! Would definitely make again. I didn’t bother straining it. I also cut back on the sugar because we don’t like it too sweet. 04 of 14 Photo by  Barb 03/15/2020 Tastes like my favourite! I wanted sugar free, so I swapped out the 2/3 c of sugar for 2/3 c dried apricots, simmered them together and pureed them in at the end. I almost missed the cayenne (I put 1/4 tsp) because it's not listed in the ingredients. Everything else I followed exactly. Anyway, the first day, I was tasting a bitterness from the apricots, but the next day it was PERFECT! Nice and thick too! I'll be making this regularly, because sugar or artificial sweetener is in all the store brands. This amount (about 3 cups) should last me a year, so I'm freezing it in portions. 05 of 14 Photo by  Birdy Velazquez 12/12/2019 06 of 14 Photo by  Greg 09/29/2019 07 of 14 Photo by  CJJones 08/16/2019 This is a great recipe! I doubled it. Ran it through a water bath and have ketchup to last me at least six months. Changes I made are as follows: I used fresh tomatoes from my garden, cooking them down, skins and all, until soft. Then ran them through a blender. Then continued with the recipe. I used organic raw sugar instead of regular white sugar. I didn't use onions because my son doesn't like them. But next time I'll chop them finely in the food processor and saute them before adding to recipe while he is not looking! I didn't have whole cloves, so I used ground cloves instead. I didn't strain anything out because after blending and cooking down everything was very smooth. 08 of 14 Photo by  Vivienne 11/08/2018 Added a little more garlic powder, onion powder, mustard powder, cayenne and salt. 09 of 14 Photo by  Vivienne 11/08/2018 Added a little more garlic powder, onion powder, mustard powder, cayenne and salt. 10 of 14 Photo by  Vivienne 11/08/2018 Added a little more garlic powder, onion powder, mustard powder, cayenne and salt. 1 2 Next You’ll Also Love Cliff's Hot Sauce 21 Ratings Spaghetti Sauce 307 Ratings Slow Cooker Marinara Sauce 1 Rating D's Famous Salsa 1,181 Ratings Pomodoro Pasta Sauce 25 Ratings Mama's Tomato Gravy 53 Ratings Grandma Prentice's Chili Sauce 1 Rating Splendicious Slow Cooker Spaghetti Sauce 77 Ratings Slow Cooker Bolognese 278 Ratings Basic Spicy Tomato Sauce 53 Ratings Spaghetti Sauce with Cauliflower 20 Ratings Basic Creole Sauce 8 Ratings Southern-Style Tomato Gravy 16 Ratings Homemade Hot Sauce with Jalapenos 1 Rating Ranchero Sauce 7 Ratings Curry Sauce 14 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: John Mitzewich
instructions: Pour tomatoes into slow cooker. Swirl 1/4 cup water in each emptied can and pour into the slow cooker. Add sugar, vinegar, onion powder, garlic powder, salt, celery salt, mustard powder, black pepper, cayenne pepper, and whole clove; whisk to combine. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Cook on High, uncovered, until mixture is reduced by half and very thick, 10 to 12 hours. Stir every hour or so. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Use an immersion blender for about 20 seconds to smooth the texture of the ketchup. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Ladle ketchup into a fine strainer and press mixture with the back of a ladle to strain out any skins and seeds. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Transfer strained ketchup to a bowl. Cool completely.;Taste and adjust salt, black pepper, and cayenne pepper as desired. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios
